text: When I feel a pull to check something or switch tasks, I notice whether it's impulse or intention.
I recognize when my attention wanders and I bring it back without judgment.
Before switching tasks, I pause to see if I chose this or if something pulled me.
I switch tasks in the middle of work without finishing what I started.
When I notice cognitive fatigue or rising irritation, I take a break before attention collapses.
I recognize when my mind moves automatically versus when I'm directing it intentionally.
Before opening a distracting app, I consider how it will affect me in the next hour.
I let notifications, open tabs, or visible apps pull my attention without recognizing the trigger.
I notice when I'm breaking focus because of emotion versus completing a natural boundary.
When I feel the urge to check something, I delay it by a few seconds to return agency to myself.
I recognize my natural focus rhythm and place my hardest tasks during peak focus windows.
I let bottom-up triggers like boredom spikes or algorithmic hooks control my attention automatically.
When I notice my attention is collapsing, I recognize it early and protect my cognitive resources.
I see the difference between intentional switching at task boundaries versus impulsive switching mid-work.
When I feel a pull, I label it as impulse versus intention and choose my response.
I let automatic behavior control my attention without building meta-awareness of what my mind is doing.
I notice when my attention window is short and I shape it with short focus cycles instead of fighting it.
When I recognize cognitive residue from switching mid-task, I complete boundaries to create clean transitions.
I notice when something external asks for my attention and I choose to respond internally first.
I let my attention be pulled by external triggers without shifting from reaction to intention.
